title: Charles Nagel
text:
Charles Nagel (August 9, 1849 – January 5, 1940) was a United States politician and lawyer from <a href="St.%20Louis%2C%20Missouri">St. Louis, Missouri</a>. He was <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20Commerce%20and%20Labor">Secretary of Commerce and Labor</a> during <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="William%20Howard%20Taft">William Howard Taft</a>'s administration (1909–1913) and was one of the key founders of the <a href="United%20States%20Chamber%20of%20Commerce">United States Chamber of Commerce</a>.
Life and career.
Nagel was born on August 9, 1849, in <a href="Colorado%20County%2C%20Texas">Colorado County, Texas</a>, the son of Friedericke (Litzmann) and Hermann Nagel. Nagel moved to a boarding school in St. Louis, Missouri, for high school and stayed to study law at <a href="Washington%20University%20Law%20School">Washington University Law School</a>. He graduated with his law degree in 1872. Nagel furthered his education by traveling to Europe and learning political economy at the <a href="University%20of%20Berlin">University of Berlin</a>.
Returning to St. Louis in 1873, Nagel joined the state bar and began to practice law. He was a member of the firm Finkelnburg, Nagel and Kirby, and later of Nagel and Kirby. His first foray into politics came when he won election to the <a href="Missouri%20House%20of%20Representatives">Missouri House of Representatives</a> in 1881, where he served until 1883. He was president of the <a href="St.%20Louis%2C%20Missouri">St. Louis</a> city council from 1893 to 1897. He also taught at St. Louis Law School (1885–1909) and was a member of the <a href="Republican%20National%20Committee">Republican National Committee</a> (1908–1912).
Nagel was a corporate attorney for <a href="Adolphus%20Busch">Adolphus Busch</a> when <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="William%20Howard%20Taft">William Howard Taft</a> chose him, in 1909, as <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20Commerce%20and%20Labor">Secretary of Commerce and Labor</a>, a position he held until the end of the Taft administration in 1913. He was the last person to serve in the post before it was separated to two <a href="United%20States%20Cabinet">cabinet</a> positions, <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20Commerce">Secretary of Commerce</a> and <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20Labor">Secretary of Labor</a>. While heading the Department of Commerce and Labor, Nagel made it more accessible to the needs of businessmen while also expanding the Bureau of Immigration and Naturalization.
Nagel was also a founder of the <a href="United%20States%20Chamber%20of%20Commerce">United States Chamber of Commerce</a>. Following his time in the cabinet, Nagel returned to the practice of law, arguing before the Supreme Court three times before his death. He died in <a href="St.%20Louis%2C%20Missouri">St. Louis, Missouri</a> on January 5, 1940 and was interred there in <a href="Bellefontaine%20Cemetery">Bellefontaine Cemetery</a>.
Family.
Nagel was married twice: first, in 1876, to Fannie Brandeis, the sister of <a href="Louis%20Dembitz%20Brandeis">Louis Dembitz Brandeis</a>, later a <a href="Associate%20Justice%20of%20the%20United%20States%20Supreme%20Court">Supreme Court justice</a>. She died in 1889 and he married Anne Shepley in 1895. He had six children, including <a href="Charles%20Nagel%20%28architect%29">Charles Nagel, Jr.</a>, an architect and curator.
